Preparing for Adulthood

  • Contact us
  • My Gloucester
  • News
  • Subscribe
  1. Home
  2. SEND
  3. Preparing for Adulthood

Growing up and moving towards adult life is a big change. If your child has SEND, planning ahead means they can get the support they need to live as independently and confidently as possible.

When transition planning begins

Transition planning must start at the Year 9 annual review (when your child is 13 or 14). From that point, every annual review of the EHC plan must include outcomes and support focused on preparing for adult life.

This does not mean your child must leave school at 16. Planning early gives everyone more time to explore options and put the right support in place.

The four areas of preparing for adulthood

The law says transition planning must cover four key areas:

Employment

Higher education, further education, employment or self-employment. This includes supported internships, apprenticeships and traineeships.

Independent living

Having choice and control over where and how the young person lives. This includes support with housing, daily living skills and managing money.

Taking part in society

Friendships, relationships, leisure activities, volunteering and being part of the community.

Being healthy

Being as healthy as possible in adult life, including managing health conditions, mental health and wellbeing.

Education and training after 16

Young people with EHC plans can stay in education or training until age 25. Options include:

  • Further education colleges with specialist SEND provision
  • School sixth forms
  • Specialist post-16 institutions (approved under section 41 of the Children and Families Act)
  • Supported internships — structured work-based learning programmes
  • Traineeships — preparation for apprenticeships or employment
  • Apprenticeships with SEND support

Rights at 16

From age 16, young people have their own legal rights under the Children and Families Act 2014. This means:

  • the young person (not just the parents) can make requests and decisions about their EHC plan
  • the young person can appeal to the SEND Tribunal in their own name
  • the council should communicate directly with the young person, as well as parents

Parents still have an important role, but the law recognises the young person's growing independence.

Moving to adult social care

If your child is likely to need social care support after they turn 18, the council must carry out a transition assessment under the Care Act 2014. This should happen at a time that is of significant benefit — usually between ages 16 and 18.

The transition assessment looks at what the young person's care and support needs are likely to be as an adult, and what services might be available.

Parents and carers may also be entitled to their own assessment of their support needs during this period.

When the EHC plan ends

An EHC plan can continue until age 25, as long as the young person is in education or training. The plan must be ceased when:

  • the young person leaves education or training
  • they reach age 25
  • the council decides the plan is no longer necessary

If you disagree with a decision to end the plan, you have the right to appeal.

Start early

Transition planning begins at the Year 9 annual review (age 13-14). Good planning early on opens up more options.

Get support

SENDIASS

Free advice on transition and preparing for adulthood.
